questions.question: A sequence of database operations that must be executed as a single unit of work.
questions.explanation: A transaction is a logical unit of work that contains one or more database operations.

questions.question: The property that ensures all operations in a transaction complete successfully or none at all.
questions.explanation: Atomicity guarantees that transactions are all-or-nothing; partial completion is not allowed.

questions.question: The property that ensures the database moves from one valid state to another.
questions.explanation: Consistency ensures that transaction execution maintains database integrity constraints.

questions.question: The property that ensures concurrent transactions don't interfere with each other.
questions.explanation: Isolation prevents concurrent transactions from seeing each other's partial results.

questions.question: The property that ensures committed changes are permanent even after system failure.
questions.explanation: Durability guarantees that committed transactions survive system crashes.

questions.question: SQL command to make transaction changes permanent.
questions.explanation: COMMIT saves all changes made during a transaction to the database permanently.

questions.question: SQL command to undo all transaction changes.
questions.explanation: ROLLBACK reverses all operations performed in the current transaction.

questions.question: Reading uncommitted data from another transaction.
questions.explanation: A dirty read occurs when one transaction reads data that another transaction has modified but not yet committed.

questions.question: A marker within a transaction allowing partial rollback.
questions.explanation: A savepoint is a named point in a transaction to which you can later roll back.

questions.question: The strictest isolation level that prevents all anomalies.
questions.explanation: Serializable is the highest isolation level, providing complete isolation between transactions.
